Nicely done and very understandable. Are you at all interested in making this example relevant to a basic understanding of physics (and not just math)? The immovable wall is what makes this problem into a "conservation of energy" scenario. Even deeper: conservation of mass / energy heavily depends on vacuum energy interacting relativistically with fundamental particles (electrons, quarks). This is why the left wall cannot move. This is why electrons are spherical (and quarks are "nearly" spherical). This is also the origin of the unnamed "force" that binds energy into the localized, temporally persistent bound fundamental particles of the Standard Model which are all as spherically perfect and identical in the quantum realm as the constant Pi can make them.

Newton imposed his own (wrong) geometric ordering of relative positions, velocities, and acceleration. Acceleration comes FIRST, not the "second" derivative with respect to time. Acceleration is the engine of locality. Without acceleration (changes of direction, not necessarily "relative"), time itself does not exist, much less a derivative of something else with respect to time. There exists ONLY time and energy. Relativity, like your model, ONLY NEEDS to work in ONE dimension in order to generate spherical bound energy and three dimensional 'timespace'. Grassmann's outer and inner vector products are all that is needed to detail the mechanism of the conservation of energy. Even though he intended it as a static model, it shows that energy is conserved by CHANGING DIRECTION, not changing form, and is never created nor destroyed.

These ideas are part of an online collaboration that solved a 50 year physics problem. The solution, a complete model of a fermion that includes all of relativity, the origin of the fundamental particles of the Standard Model, the reason no Higgs boson is needed to explain gravitation or the origin of inertial mass, and much more will be published in all its glory in late June, 2025.

This was awesome! Have you considered doing a follow-up on Dirichlet's theorem about Chebyshev's bias? For example, when you showed the histogram of primes 1, 3, 7, and 9 mod 10, there is a bias towards 3 and 7 mod 10 (because these are non-squares). Even though the categories all have 25% in the limit, there is quantitatively more primes 3 and 7 mod 10.  The primes race is really compelling and not too hard to understand.

Fun fact about Euler Totient Function: There exists no output which is odd. Always of the form 2n. Proved this in my number theory class not too long ago and it was fun. The set of numbers relatively prime to m and which are not divisible by another element of R(m) are called the reduced residue set of m, and it has a bunch of fun properties, for instance: the sum of all elements of the reduced residue set is congruent to 0 mod m.

Each prime can be found by building it with the previous primes.
One multipled with one added one makes two prime : 1*1+1=2
1*1-1=0 1*1+1=2 prime p=[2]
2*2-+1=(3,5) twin primes p=[2,3,5]
2*3-+1=(5,7) twin primes p=[2,3,5,7]

There are two moments that stand out to me as moments of "Hey, I'm rediscovering math!"
The first was in high school calculus, where I used the power rule to figure out the derivative rule of sqrt(x).
The second was more recently when I figured out that 99/70 is a very close approximation for sqrt(2). My rationale was that 1/sqrt(2) = 0.7071... which I recognized as being very close to 0.7070... repeating. Since a repeating decimal string is just that string divided by an equally long string of 9's, this becomes 70/99. Take the reciprocal of that, and sqrt(2) becomes roughly equal to 99/70. Sure enough, the percent error is 0.005%

And just to be clear, when I say the percent error is 0.005%, I mean the percent error of numerical value. I am aware that 99/70 does not predict digits accurately beyond the first few.

There are 8 numbers relatively prime to 2, 3, and 5 in every sequence of numbers L*m+1 to L*(m+1) for L = 30 and m>0, with the relative primes evenly divided between the 1, 3, 7, and 9 residues modulo 10. For each successive prime p, multiply L by p, and begin the sequence at the smallest value of 30*m+1 greater than p. Eliminating the multiples of p removes L/p numbers, evenly divided between the 1, 3, 7, and 9 residues modulo 10. Thus the number of possible true primes is thinned out at the same rate in each residue modulo 10. The numbers less than p^2 are true primes.

A group of California lawmakers is working on a bill that stipulates the well-known numerical constant π (Greek letter pi), which defines the ratio of the circumference of a circle to its diameter, be set to a single-digit value of 3 for all texts, tests, and projects in primary, middle school, high school, as well as most college courses. They maintain that this would reduce stress on students who are grappling with many uncertainties, including those caused by the pandemic.

“Setting pi equal to 3 will avoid the need for students to struggle over whether they should use 3, 3.1, 3.14, or even more digits,” offered one source as rationale. ”Let’s be honest, there’s no need to go beyond 3 for most applications, so the use of more digits of that irrational number is, well, not rational. Also, where do you tell the student to stop? Some students will become trapped by worrying about the endless string of digits with which they are dealing.”

While pi would be set at 3 for pre-college students, the proposed bill further mandates that the 3 value also be used by all non-STEM (science, technology, engineering, math) college students. At the same time, students majoring in STEM disciplines can be instructed to use as many digits as the course leader feels appropriate, from the popular 3.14 through 3.14159, or even more. It specifically doesn’t prevent professionals such as engineers, scientists, and architects from using as many digits as they feel are needed.

Some of the proponents further argue for the single-digital value by saying that using more digits implies that some figures are “more significant” than others and thus sends a wrong message, in that all digits should be treated with equivalent significance. As one proponent says, “After all, who can say that the fifth digit after the decimal point—for pi, that’s a ‘9’—is truly less significant than the fourth one, a “5?” By staying with just 3 alone, we avoid the need to be judgmental.”

To further bolster their case, the legislators point out that use of 3 for pi has precedent in the King James Bible (First Kings, chapter 7, verses 23 and 26): "And he [Hiram] made a molten sea, ten cubits from the one rim to the other it was round all about, and...a line of thirty cubits did compass it round about....And it was a hand breadth thick...." along with a very similar text in 2 Chronicles 4:2. Therefore, the use of pi as equal to just 3 alone is a time-tested, reasonable approximation that has been used successfully for thousands of years.

Oh, come now! Quoting California Legislators' ideas as "new". Rounding Pi to 3 has been standard Engineering Good Practice for centuries. Working out new ideas on a cocktail napkin, back of an envelope, or even a mini-Post-it has always required rounding/truncation to make the calculations fit. We've always left the dog-work of forcing it to work to the green newbies in the office, anyhow.

April Fools?

Legislators should spend the taxpayer's money on other things and leave the decisions to use a specific value of Pi to the teachers as they see fit. Let the teachers decide which value of pi the students should use. It is a waste of taxpayers' money to spend legislative time in trivial pursuits.

=============================
If x and y are positive integers, then
all numbers of the form (6k+1) are composite if
k = 6xy+x+y
or
k = 6xy-x-y

Numbers of the form (6k + 1) for which k does not satisfy any of these conditions are simple.
=============================
If x and y are positive integers, then
all numbers of the form (6k-1) are composite if
k = 6xy-x+y
or,
k = 6xy+x-y

Numbers of the form (6k - 1) for which k does not satisfy any of these conditions are simple.
=============================

I noticed a peculiar mathematical phenomenon, while looking at the calculation of 662314 days with different length years (don't ask). 

The math is 662314/359 = 1,844.8857938718662952646239554318, which is 1844 and 318 days. That is, 0.8857938718662952646239554318 x 359 = 318 days. 

Further, 0.8857938718662952646239554318 x 360, instead of 359, is 318.88579387186629526462395543175. The exact same decimal. The difference at the end is simply due to the places my calculator can produce. 

That is, we can do this into infinity.

I noticed that the result is due to the relationship between 359 and 360, or any odd number and that number plus 1.  

For instance, if we take 663840 days, which is 1844 x 360, and divide it by 359, we get 1,849.1364902506963788300835654596, which is 1849 years and 49 days. The remainder of  0.1364902506963788300835654596 x 360 is 49.136490250696378830083565456.This means it is not the large number we start with that creates this phenomenon.   
If we take 662314 and divide it by three, we get 220,771.33333333333333333333333333.

The remainder multiplied by 3 results in 1. If it is multiplied by 4, it results in 1.3333333333333333333333

I do not know what this rule is, since without a name for it, it is very difficult to look up on Google.

I'd like to see the pattern in primes if there were any. But there are none except all prime waves cross at zero. Light waves of different lengths, all starting at zero and going off into infinity is the way to think of prime numbers. I call them prime waves. They go both directions from zero, positive and negative. 

So for example the number 3. It would generate a prime wave that crosses the number line at zero, then 3, then 6, then 9 and so forth out into infinity.

The thing about primes is you have to travel the wave until it crosses off all of the numbers in it's path as it crosses the number line. Each new prime number starting a new prime wave and all of the prime waves combined traveling out from zero until they don't cross out a number on the number line. And this new prime becoming a new prime wave traveling out with the other prime waves at the speed of light crossing out all of the multiples of the existing prime numbers until the next prime number is found. Our speed is the speed of light. Thus you could calculate how far the prime waves traveling at the speed of light would travel in a year. And thus how many new primes can theoretically be found per year using the speed of light as the basis for calculation.

Yeah I don't see any new revelations here about pi or primes. When I was a kid in school pi was this mysterious number that was used to calculate circles. Yet it is so easy to make pi something that even a small child can grasp. If you calculate the circumference of a square, lets say each side is 1, then to go around that square is 4. Now set a circle in that square and the circumference is 3.14 or pi. So the ratio is 4 to 3.14 The ratio of the circumference of a square to a circle's circumference that fits inside that square.

And really that ratio is not really just 4 to 3.14. It is also the ratio of one side of the square or 1 to one side of the circle, or 1/4th of the circle or .785. So 1 to .785, that is the exact same ratio as pi.

I fondly remember the time when in 5th class I re-invented the Gauss-Formula for the sum of all integers from 1 to n. I wasn't clever enough to duplicate the number line in reverse order, but I was clever enough to realize that summing up pairs from front and end of the line would always end up with the same sum. It was a lot of effort to "simplify" or describe in terms of mathematical notation what I was doing, but after a whole lot of time, I got to the answer that is n*(n+1)/2. When I learned about that formula some time later, I knew why it was correct before we proved it formally on the board.

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from math import cos,sin

def circleplot(L):
X=[i*cos(i) for i in L]
Y=[i*sin(i) for i in L]
plt.scatter(X,Y)
plt.show()

def primelist(n):
L=[True for i in range(n)]
L[0]=L[1]=False

for i in range(2,n):
if L[i]:
k=2
while i*k<n:
L[k*i]=False
k+=1

M=[]
for i in range(n):
if L[i]:
M.append(i)
return M

circleplot(primelist(20000))

Id be interested in a video about something my calculus teacher showed us one day, that's in a similar vein to this topic. She called it 'patterned randomness', but i was never able to find anything more on it.

What she showed us was this simple algorithm:
1. lay 3 points, ABC, such that they make an equilateral triangle
2. place a 4th point in the middle
3. roll a die. based on the result, go halfway from the 4th point to A if you get a 1 or 2, halfway to B if a 3 or 4, halfway to C if you get a 5 or 6, and make a new point.
4. repeat 3 from the new point.

An interesting pattern emerges :)

Here is a somewhat simpler way to find primes. Draw a hexagon and then arrange all numbers around the points of the hexagon. Draw  rays out from the points of the hexagon and you will find that all primes fall on only two rays (the ones beginning at the 1 ray and the 5 ray). The two rays hold only primes and prime products (the product of two primes). By creating spirals around the hexagon with a new spiral starting at each prime product the spirals will intersect at ONLY prime products, and will intersect ALL prime products. remove the numbers on the spirals and you will have only (and all) primes except 2 and 3.

After I saw this video I really wanted to recreate this phenomenon so I created a little program in Java, but more specifically Processing or P.5 to visualize this and it is amazing. I'm not sure if this comment will get flagged for spam, but I'll share the code below if any of you want to copy and paste it into your Processing environment. The program automatically generates prime numbers and adds them to the canvas, although you can zoom in and out with your scroll wheel if you want. Anyway, enjoy (:


int[] primes=new int[1];

int showing=1;

void setup() {
background(0);
primes[0]=1;
size(1000, 1000, P2D);
noStroke();
}

void draw() {
if (frameRate>59) primes=morePrimes(primes, 1000);
if (frameRate>50) primes=morePrimes(primes, 1000);
if (frameRate>40) primes=morePrimes(primes, 1000);
else primes=morePrimes(primes, 1);
if (minute()%5==0 && frameRate>1) {
showing=primes.length;
showPrimes();
}
}

int[] morePrimes(int[] primes, int more) {
int number=primes[primes.length-1];
int made=0;
while (made<more) {
number=number+1;
if (isPrime(number)) {
primes=append(primes, number);
made++;
}
}
return primes;
}

boolean isPrime(int n) {
int max=int(sqrt(n));
for (int i=2; i<max; i++) {
if (n%i==0) return false;
}
return true;
}

void mouseWheel(MouseEvent event) {
if (event.getCount()>0) showing=int((showing+1)*1.05);
else showing=int(showing*0.95)-1;
if (showing>primes.length) primes=morePrimes(primes, showing-primes.length);
if (showing>0) {
showPrimes();
}
}

void mousePressed() {
showPrimes();
}

void showPrimes() {
background(0);
int last=primes[showing-1];
println(primes.length, last);
for (int i=0; i<showing; i++) {
plot(primes[i], last);
}
}

void plot(int n, int last) {
circle(n*cos(n)*(float)width/last/2+width/2, n*sin(n)*(float)height/last/2+height/2, 2);
}

In math, prime numbers are whole numbers greater than one that have only two factors. 1 and the number itself. Prime numbers are divisible only by the number 1 or itself. It was very interesting how you showed how primes split up among the residue classes. Dirichlet's theorem, also called the Dirichlet prime number theorem, states that for any two positive coprime integers a and d, there are infinitely many primes of the form a + nd, where n is also a positive integer. From where do we acquire “deep facts”? The video first presents itself as a potentially puerile plumbing of the shallower end of such a question, then follows a line of reasoning that gradually slides into the greater morass of pure mathematics. The presenter considers a fact “deep” when its meaning carries consequences for our understanding of other significant facts, presenting math as a logical web that remains taut enough to vibrate from infinite end to infinite end. The path of the presentation is deceptively simple to follow at first, demanding only that we understand the basic graphing of integers to see the picture it paints, but blossoms into a beguiling and elegant demonstration of how blueprints for richly complex mathematical constructs such as Dirichlet’s theorem are cultivated from the raw earth of mathematical logic.


The relative clarity of the presentation proffers a glimpse of the wider world of math, a logical world undisturbed by the chaos of our own. It suggests an underlying structure to the cosmos, a comfortable regimentation of reality that promises endless treasures waiting to be apprehended by the powers of reason. It is an enchanting promise that explains how people can, like Pythagoras, sacrifice their lives on the altar of arithmetic.

I had a similar, if significantly simpler, math exploration moment a while back. I'd been learning Python and decided to multiply numbers out to be many thousands of digits long to see if the software could handle it. In the end, I had a text file with ~1 million digits formed by a lot of multiplication. I decided to see how the digits were proportioned and was pretty shocked to find no matter how I created the number (barring obvious exceptions like (10*10)^1000) every digit appeared the same number of times. I had thought maybe (5*5)^10000 would show some bias, after all 5, 25, 125, 625 are made up of between 100% and 33% 5's right?

Seems obvious to me now, but at the time I felt pretty clever for stumbling across that. :)

Every 6 radians is very close to 2pi, and since each (p,p) plot, even the (n,n) plot can create a similar spirals. If you create a radian graph and plot these points you can see that every radial curve moves outward and counterclockwise which gives the Archimedes spiral. 6 radian equals roughly 343.775 degrees in a 360-degree circle. Which is only 16.225 degrees away from 360 degrees, since this shortage continues each 6 radians with the x coordinate growing n+1 each time gives a slightly larger curve. As this continues indefinitely you create the spiral shown in the video. As we continue to zoom out of the infinite graph plots using prime numbers only, we create new patterns that are just as elegant and mesmerizing. In the end this is an arbitrary pattern, and just a play on numbers using specific constraints. It is exciting to play with numbers and accidentally find a pattern or new algorithm that can explain some of the chaos within our reality. It’s amazing that just patterns of numbers can unlock new technology and ideas for people around the world. Math is the key to getting closer to figuring out what all “this” (universe) means.

While taking a number theory course in graduate school during the 70s, I was trying to find patterns for the appearance of twin primes.    I noted that they tended to reside at the edges of a spiraling lattice and derived a recursive formula.    Shortly thereafter, I discovered Ulam's work.   He discovered, developed, and published the finding at least a decade earlier.   Somewhat disappointing, but not uncommon in mathematics.

Apparently the problem about distribution of prime numbers can be simplified by only using residue class mod 6 +1, but you need to choose total numbers as a domain. After you make modulo operation on it, you will get the answer why 5 lies next to 7 and 11 next to 13 ;) I also encourage to try to investigate this number series as I am hypothesizing that every prime number belongs to it. It also shows some decent features like the numbers wchich aren't primes are only to be made by a multiplication of 2 numbers which are greater than zero(in the series) or 2 numbers which are not. For example -5 *(-5)= 25 is simply 1+6*4. 7*7=49 is 1+6*8. However if you multiply -5*7=-35 and if you +1 it, it won't be able to divide it by 6. That's where modulo comes with help. To make your analysis easier I recommend making 2 subsequent series 5+6*x and 7+6*x. You may find veeeery fancy features while investigating the subject. You are welcome. Have fun ;)

I once did an extensive, multi-approach analysis to Prime numbers. I got the intuitive sense that prime numbers 'jump', almost like gears activating one-behind-the-other in succession, after completing their first cycle. So, first gear turns, goes full cycle, and on its next cycle there are now 2 gears turning.


If we're able to figure out the composition of these analogous 'gears' as mathematical expressions, we may be able to come up with a generalized equation for Prime Numbers, which actually used to be a Clay Institute Millenium prize (though they removed it). This is a touchy topic, though, because there are a lot of implications to the function of prime numbers. It could drastically change the world if such a discovery were made, though possibly not in a good way lol.

The abundance of prime numbers is of greater significance than how many there are to some limit.
Half of all integers are even, and are therefore composites.
One-third of all integers are multiples of three and are therefore composites, but half of these have already been counted.
To find the abundance we must add one-half to one-half of one-third [1/2 + 1/(2×3)], which equals two-thirds.
One-fifth of all integers are multiples of five, but one-half and another one-third have already been counted.
To find the abundance we must add one-thirtieth to two-thirds [2/3 + 1/(2×3×5)], which equals seven-tenths or 70%.
One-seventh of all integers are multiples of seven, but one-half, one-third, and one-fifth of these have already been counted.
To find the abundance we must add one-two hundred tenth [7/10 + 1/(2×3×5×7)], less than one-half of one percent to 70%.
To find the abundance this issue continues with eleven, thirteen, seventeen, and beyond which add receding tenths of percentages: less than one-twentieth, less than one-two hundredth, less than one-two thousandth and so on.
Continuing this sequence through forty-one yields 70.5230171791801%.
Prime abundance must approximate to the converse of this: 29.4769828208199%.
The abundance of primes found through three billion, however, amounts to only 4.81243122%.
Where are all the primes?
The answer can only be that there is a limit to the sequential difference of primes, and that limit must be quite small in relation to an infinite number line.

I wondered for years why mathematicians measure angles in multiples of Pi. Today I understand that Radian means to measure an angle by walking along the unit circle and thus it also seems to me the most natural way to measure angles.
Thus you can explain the polar coordinates (p,p) without mentioning Pi or Radians in this way: Walk one unit from the origin to the right, along the x axis. Then walk p units along the unit circle anti-clockwise. Then walk (p-1) units along the ray from the origin through your current position.
Alternatively: Walk p units from the origin to the right along the x axis. Then follow the circle of radius p by p² units anti-clockwise.

Take any positive integer "n". Then take any factor of "n", "f". Now take the set of coprimes of "n" and find their remainders when divided by "f". The results will be evenly distributed among the coprimes of "f".

Dirichlet's Theorem might be hard to prove but it's pretty intuitive to think about, if you structure your argument in terms of prime density as n goes to infinity of each residue class:


Each spiral in the picture has a certain density of primes which is determined by the primes which are coprime with the "spiral number" (i.e. the number of turns you need to make to get the next element of that class). Since every residue class for a given spiral number is coprime with the same primes, the density will be determined the same way, with the same eventual numbers, so it will be the same on average for each class. Boom.

Playung with numbers can often get you insights that we difficult to learn in textbooks. I had an experiment playing around with damage multiplies on a video game I was coding... Multiple weaknesses and status effects that multiply and divide by 2. It led to me discovering how exponents work and that I could literally add up the multiplies in the exponent... Which later became the basis for all my stats such that each point of a stat increased the 'power' of that state by 1/10th .. or 10 points to double it. This way I could add or subtract stats and make them powers of 2 to get the result. (2^(x/10)) Any adding of 10 doubles the result and any subtracting of 10 halves the result.

This is an insight into numbers I probably would never have gotten if I wasn't playing around with them to see how they worked.

Important error correction: In the video, I say that Dirichlet showed that the primes are equally distributed among allowable residue classes, but this is not historically accurate. (By "allowable", here, I mean a residue class whose elements are coprime to the modulus, as described in the video). What he actually showed is that the sum of the reciprocals of all primes in a given allowable residue class diverges, which proves that there are infinitely many primes in such a sequence. Incidentally, his tactics also show that these residue classes have the same "density", but for an alternate formulation of density than the one shown in the video.

Dirichlet observed this equal distribution numerically and noted this in his paper, but it wasn't until decades later that this fact was properly proved, as it required building on some of the work of Riemann in his famous 1859 paper. If I'm not mistaken, I think it wasn't until Vallée Poussin in (1899), with a version of the prime number theorem for residue classes like this.

In many ways, this was a very silly error for me to have let through. It is true that this result was proven with heavy use of complex analysis, and in fact, it's in a complex analysis lecture that I remember first learning about it. But of course, this would have to have happened after Dirichlet because it would have to have happened after Riemann!

My apologies for the mistake. If you notice factual errors in videos that are not already mentioned in the video's description or pinned comment, don't hesitate to let me know.

"Mod" is short for "modulus" from the Latin for "measure" and is used for a whole bunch of fields of maths related to how numbers compare(modular arithmetic is when number wrap around at a point, the modulus function is it's distance from 0, conformal modulus is the size of a family of curves, etc).
"Residue" is about taking a set or function and deriving a single value from it in some way, in this context it is referring to something called a congruence which is a property where two numbers are a distance apart that's a multiple of a third you're interested in with the residue being the third number that is a constant factor in the differences between the numbers(in the context you're talking about it's 6).

It's the combination of the two that tells you that you're looking at the remainder, neither word alone means what you're saying it does, and while I get you're trying to simplify things you should probably avoid simplifying in a way that's flat out wrong(since the meaning is more like the single digit that describes the group of sets of numbers where in modular arithmetic the differences are the same is 6).

One implication he didn't go into:
When plotting the numbers in whole number radians, each new number was 1/2pi rotations from the last one. So, the numbers made a spiral arm every time they encountered a number that was close to the denominator of a rational approximation of 1/2pi (that is to say, close to twice the numerator of a rational approximation of pi itself). But what if we didn't want to make spirals? What if we wanted all of our points to be as far away from other points as possible, *in every direction*? (Why we would need to do this is a point I'll come back to later.) If you're making spiral arms, there's a lot of space in between the arms that's wasted, and much less space between two neighbors on the same arm. Is there a way to avoid this?
Well, if we want to find a number that gives us no spirals, we need it to have as few rational approximations as possible, (some of you might see where I'm going with this) we can look at continued fractions, since as explained in that Mathologer video, every time you encounter a large number in a number's continued fraction, you can truncate the sequence there and get a pretty good approximation. Thus, the ultimate not-close-to-any-rational-number number would have a continued fraction with numbers as low as possible. Ideally, made up of all 1's. This number happens to be (sqrt(5)+1)/2, known as the Golden Ratio.
But getting back to why we would need to find points as far away from each other as possible: Well, what if we were a plant putting out seeds? We have a chemical process that rotates by a certain amount and then makes a seed. And we want those seeds to be spread out as efficiently as possible so that they don't have to compete for resources.
If you've heard that the Golden Ratio shows up in nature, this is why.

Here is some Python code for anyone wanting to plot their own prime spirals:

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from math import sin, cos


def get_primes_up_to(n: int):
assert n >= 2
numbers = set(range(n, 1, -1))
primes = []
while numbers:
prime = numbers.pop()
primes.append(prime)
numbers.difference_update(range(prime*2, n+1, prime))
return primes

number_of_primes = 10000 # change 10000 to whatever you like
marker_size = 2 if number_of_primes >= 100000 else 8 if number_of_primes <= 1000 else \
2*(number_of_primes-1000)/99000 - 8*(number_of_primes-100000)/99000
primes = get_primes_up_to(number_of_primes)
x = [prime * cos(prime) for prime in primes]
y = [prime * sin(prime) for prime in primes]

fig = plt.figure(dpi=600)
plt.scatter(x, y, s=marker_size) # s is the size of each marker
plt.show()

It only requires the Matplotlib library.

At 21:37 it is said that exploring numbers for fun will give you a better appreciation for related math concepts once you are introduced to them. I can attest to that as follows. I was trying to write a computer program to find a group of red pixels on the screen (something like finding a red pool ball on a green pool table). I always started at the center of the screen and worked my way out because the red pixels were most likely going to be near the screen center in my situation. I realized polar coordinates would be helpful with this expanding search, but every formula I tried made my search spiral too wide as I went out from the center, causing me to miss some red dots on the screen. After a little while I stumbled upon Archimedes' Spiral as described around 1:27 in this video. That was my solution. So when I reached the 2 minute mark in this video I was very comfortable with what was being said. I fully understand Archimedes' Spiral the moment is was mentioned. During the more spiral sections, the polar distance dominates the arc length so we naturally connect a spiral pattern along the arc length, while at higher zoom levels the arc length dominates the polar distance, so we want to draw straighter lines along the polar distance. all primes are 1 or 5 above a multiple of 6?
i always used leibnitzs 6n +/- 1 for this. basically it means the same in the end. except for 2 and 3 ofc. for 6*1 it's 5 and 7, 6*2 it's 11 and 13, 6*3 it's 17 and 19, 6*4 it's 23 and 25 and the first where there is no prime pair, 6*5 it's 29 and 31 and so on......
there is 3 fundamental groups following the first 3 primes 1, 2 and 3 and yes i know that 1 isn't considered prime by mathematicians.. but think about this:
1 embodies the most significant property of a prime: to be not divisible but to be exact 1 is also not divisible by itself. so you could say it's the one number of them all that is most consequent in not being divisible of all numbers.
now the definition of what is prime was exactly choosen to exclude 1 from them. i mean in the past there were times that considered 1 as a prime. but ofc as there is more to a prime than divisibility, meaning there is also the aspect that primes make up all other numbers you could for every number there is also add an infinite number of 1's in prime factorization. this is why we excluded 1 ultimately. but it also unfortunately makes it harder to see the following point about the 3 fundamental groups of numbers:
(and before you brush this off as pointless numerology, euler himself was desperately searching for a hidden order withing numbers so the quest for the fundamental order within our numbers is still going on today)


1, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17, 19, 23, 25, 29,... and so on.. this is the first group following 1. it includes all primes and all non primes that are neither divisible by 2 or 3 and they are all odd. always grouped in pairs.
2, 4, 8, 10, 14, 16, 20, 22, 26, 28,... and so on.. this is the second group following 2. it includes all numbers divisible by 2 but not divisible by 3 and they are all even. also always grouped in pairs.
3, 6, 9, 12, 15, 18, 21, 24, 27, 30,... and so on.. this is the third group following 3. it includes all numbers divisible by 3 alternating between one odd and one even number. never grouped in pairs.


so if you write this out you can ofc continue a little more but you will see that all numbers fall into these 3 groups and here is the interesting thing:
all primes larger than 2 and 3 follow the 6n +/- 1 pattern meaning every prime will fall onto a potential prime pair spot around the multiples of 6.
now to the interesting part. what about the numbers that fall on these spots but aren't prime? the first number is 25, the second is 35. what is interesting about them is if you factorize them they are exclusively divisible by primes equal or larger than 5 our first true prime in the 6n +/- 1 pattern but NEVER 2 and 3.
it's not an odd coincidence tho. it's the natural order of numbers categorized into 3 neat groups that each have a root prime 1, 2 or 3 and that dictates the order and properties of all members within a group until infinity.


so fundamentaly 1, 2 and 3 are truely special primes or with other words: the first 3 natural numbers are the only primes that literally hit the nail on its head considering the origin of the term prime and truely can be called "the first".


and this shows why the definition of prime numbers is rather unfortunate. it dilutes the fact that all primes follow 1 in the 6n +/- 1 pattern which is NOT the case for 2 and 3. i mean i'm not saying we should change this definition. it proofed itself and is absolutely okay for applied mathematics. for number theory and research in this area however there should be a disclaimer about the 2 types of primes if anyone is interested to grasp the essence of the prime distribution within the natural numbers.


to come to an end i want to give you all a quote from the pythagorean philolaos that might sound a little dusty to be fair but it's still current and will be true back then, now and until eternity:
"number, indeed, has two proper kinds, odd and even, and a third mixed together from both, the even-odd. of each of the two kinds there are many shapes, of which each thing itself gives signs."
i wonder could this be used by a computer algorithm to find prime numbers faster for encryption?

If you move the individual line from the second group of three to the first group of three, respecting its original group position, you will turn the first group of three into a group of four, if you repeat the process, you will make 3 groups of four out of 4 groups of three, in other words, if you take a look at the position of each individual line in the 4 groups of three, you will notice that you can fill the gaps using the individual lines from the other ones. To illustrate, I will translate it into zeros and ones for you to visualize it:

These are the 4 groups of three...


0111 (first)
1011 (second)
1101 (third)
1110 (fourth)

You can move the 1 from the second group and place it in the gap of the first group, like this:

1111 (first)
0011 (second)
1101 (third)
1110 (fourth)

And you can move the 1 from the third group and place it in the gap of the fourth group, like this:

1111 (first)
0011 (second)
1100 (third)
1111 (fourth)

And finally, you can merge the second group with the third group and make a whole group of four, like this:

1111 (first)
0000 (second)
1111 (third)
1111 (fourth)

Why is it interesting? Because I counted 71 groups in total, 67 groups of four and 4 groups of three, and I wondered why does it have to be 71 in total? And why all groups have four lines except for these 4 groups that have three lines and one gap? Each one of these has one gap, there're 4 gaps in total, if 4 lines form 1 group, then, merge the 4 groups of three and you will have 3 groups of four, 1 less group, in other words, 71-1=70.
That's all.

Just in case anyone was wondering, the proof that there are infinite primes is a very simple one-liner:
"If we assume that there are only finitely many primes (say N), then their product+1 (say A) is not divisible by any of them, implying that we would find primes outside of those N in A's prime factors (possibly A itself) - contradicting our assumption."

I really like another appearance of Dirichlet's theorem, it is a nice mathematical prank:
Like in the game 7-Boom! or Fizz-Buzz, N people count together in a circle integers, with an additional rule: whenever one is about to say a prime number, he shall say 'Boom' instead.
However, every person gets a residue class mod N, which means that if you are a place that have a common divisor with N, you will end up saying almost only composite numbers and you won't have to think a lot, whereas if you are in a position relatively prime with N, you will have infinite primes in your residue, and you will have to think a lot every turn.
You can use it as a prank to other people that don't know this game, when you arrange the order and let them to struggle and check for primes, while you just add N every turn without thinking...

This concept in general is related to why fibonacci spirals/the golden ratio crop up in the geometry of many plants' body structures. The sunflower, for example, grows its inflorescence by spiraling out; each floret comes a little bit further out from the center and with a fixed turning angle.

The mathologer video mentions this, but rational approximations of the golden ratio are about as bad as is possible, so by refining to a turning angle of 2pi/(phi^2), it creates extremely noisy spirals (which, if you were to count them, you'd find them to be fibonacci numbers for the same reason). This geometry packs much more tightly, and allows the sunflower to maximize the number of florets on its disc.

What I love about that is that people tend to go very mystical with the golden ratio and fibonacci numbers. Here, we find that there is actually something to that and it's not all a bunch of nonsense. With a little patience, we unfold it and find a deeper beauty that we would've missed if we jumped the gun and yelled "magic!".

About @20:56 ... in the 8 / 9 residue classes (the upper two pics), the sequence of histogram bars to which each number is assigned (i.e. how numbers hop from bar to bar) is random, or follows some complex, periodic pattern. In the r mod 44 case (bottom right), the sequence is visually simpler: the numbers "scroll" over the histogram bars evenly, from left to right. My guess is that the reason is that we're counting in base 10. That is, with r mod 8 or r mod 9, the distances between adjacent members of a residue group are awkwardly close to 10, which introduces randomness and the numbers hop all over the place. If we were counting numbers in base 50 or 100, you'd see the nice "scrolling" effect in all cases.

Math for math's sake has always been criticized by those that aren't math-oriented, but the simple fact is that we do not have the context to know what knowledge is or is not "useful". The abstract and "pointless" often has a way of coming into the real world and revolutionizing our understanding. Non-Euclidean geometry was a fun little game and somewhat useful for cartography, but once Einstein described spacetime, we found that we already knew so much about it.
Math is the purest form of exploration; don't let anyone say that there's nothing worth seeing over that hill. They haven't been there and they're not equipped or qualified to say anything so definitively.

My recent math play has been with what I call sparse balanced base systems.
Basically, I chanced upon the observation that all integers have a unique representation as the sum of positive or negative powers of two where no two adjacent powers are used. This can be made more compact by writing the number as either -2, -1, 0, +1, or +2 times a power of 4 where adjacent sqits cannot be a 1 following a 2 regardless of the signs of the 1 or the 2.
And then I tried to figure out how to do math with these numbers in that base system and found that it would probably take 4 times the logic gates and double the time to do addition this way. But it ended up leading me to Fibonacci coding, a different and more compact coding scheme which also has some interesting features, and happens to be even less practical for doing arithmetic.

I found something, while I was in college, that a mathematician thought was interesting.

I went to school for computer science, AKA programming. I was playing around with primes - outputting prime numbers into binary and trying to find a pattern. What I noticed is for any prime number, in binary, you will find another prime number with that prime number expressed within it in terms of binary.


Take for example 7. In binary this is (111). You'll find this in 23 (10-111), 29 (111-01), and 59 (111-011). Let's continue the pattern: 59 (111011) can be found in 239 (111011-11). Let's go even deeper: 239 (11101111) is in 9967 (100110-11101111). 9967 (10011011101111) is in 39869 (10011011101111-01). You could do this with decimal, but this pattern occurs much more often in binary. What's going on here?

[WARNING: Long, rambling post ahead]



For a time, I played around with prime numbers in the following way: For a given prime 'p', I found that the numbers from 2 to 'p-2' could be paired off in such a way that the products would all leave a remainder of 1 when divided by 'p'. As an example: for the prime number 7, I saw that 2x4 and 3x5 (8 and 15, respectively) both have remainders of 1 when divided by 7. (I skipped 1 and 'p-1' since each of these would pair with itself. In this example, both 1x1 and 6x6 leave remainders of 1 when divided by 7.)



A slightly larger example: p=13. Here, I paired off the numbers from 2 to 11 as follows: 2x7, 3x9, 4x10, 5x8, and 6x11. In all cases, the product (14, 27, 40, 40, 66) leaves a remainder of 1 when divided by 13.



Then I focused on 5x8 ... because 5+8=13. I saw that no such pair exists for 7, but such pairs DO exist for 5 (2 & 3), 17 (4 & 13), and 29 (12 & 17).



I concluded that a prime number 'p' has a 'special pair', a & b, such that a+b=p and ab leaves a remainder of 1 when divided by p (i.e., "congruent to 1 mod p") ... if and only if p is 1 more than a multiple of 4; that is to say, a Pythagorean Prime.



Then I dug deeper. For the first four such primes (5, 13, 17, 29), I found the pairs 2 & 3, 5 & 8, 4 & 13, and 12 & 17. I saw that no number repeated, and some numbers seemed to get skipped. Like, I found that 6 could be paired with 31 (6+31=37 and 6x31 = 186 leaves a remainder of 1 when divided by 37). But, I couldn't find ANY number to pair with 7 ... or 18 or 21, for that matter.





After some figuring, I looked at the expression n^2+1 for each of these numbers, and found this:



7^2+1 = 50 = 2 x 5 x 5 ... no prime factor greater than 7

18^2+1 = 325 = 5 x 5 x 13 ... no prime factor greater than 18

21^2+1 = 442 = 2 x 13 x 17 ... no prime factor greater than 21



I concluded the following: For any number 'n' greater than 1, if n^2+1 has a prime factor 'p' greater than 'n', then 'n' and 'p-n' form the 'special pair' for 'p'.



So for example: 6^2+1 = 37, and since 37-6=31, I have the 'special pair' for 37: 6 & 31

Or take 9: 9^2+1 = 82 = 2 x 41, and since 41-9=32, I have the 'special pair' for 41: 9 & 32





I don't know if there is any practical use for any of this, but it was fun to discover. And the comments section of this video felt like as good a place as any to get this off my chest.

Following after 21:38 is some of the best advice out there. In sixth grade and before I was ok at math, got Cs on tests, and so on. During my seventh-grade math class, I realized I could not take math 8, and then I tested out of algebra I. Around the end of that year I became fascinated by watching some people do calculus. The next year I took geometry and tested out of algebra II then at the beginning of the year precalculus so I could take AB calculus and the BC exam (where I got a 5). In the course of that ninth-grade year, I taught myself many of the concepts and methods of multivariable calc, linear, some differential equations, and dipped my feet in a ton of other things. This following year I've explored many parts of category theory, abstract algebra, and other pure math.


I started becoming interested in math and later algebra when a girl explained to me the box method for long multiplication and I got a book about math for Christmas, I think, about unsolved problems. I loved the new symbols and equations, and the power that it looked like they had. Most importantly, realized that it was messily complex and beautiful. With all the things that had just been, invented, it felt like I could too. The whole time I vowed never to use a textbook - to ponder a question and come up with my own answer. That way, everything I knew felt like it could've been invented by me, and that I saw not a manipulation of characters, but a universal idea. Sometimes I'd continue to the same thing, like solve the quadratic formula for a month, until I figured it out. No matter how long it took, at some point, in the end, it always comes faster, and I also owe my ongoing love of math to it.


Another thing I've learned. There's no magic or 'thinking outside the box'; all of your actions, in math and life in general, force us to improve our thinking. The way to do that is not by trying to think about some unintuitive thing you've never heard of, but using what you already know; it's about creating clarity of thought, and asking what you know about but aren't taking into account that's causing fuzzy thoughts and stopping you. You can't take into account what you don't know, only what you do, so think about that thing - on the tip of your tongue - that you are conscious of but can't think of the words to apply it. It may not be the answer society excepts (at the time, anyway) but it will always serve you best; sometimes, the question you're starting with is not well enough defined for you to give such an answer, which is after all important since the question along with its context, alone, always tells you what the answer is.

If you type "Spiral Enya", Google will show a video on youtube showing an animated rotating spiral.
I spent hours playing with this software, trying to rotate the spiral by arbitrary angles while displaying an large number of point.
Short story: It became clear to me that the spiral show visible lines when the angle is close to an integer divided by an integer.


For example, given the prime number 7, the spiral show aligned lines for the angle 1/7 (the main prime) and all other fraction (2/7, 3/7, 4/7, 5/7 and 6/7). The angle 7/7 is identical to 0/7, 8/7 same as 1/7, etc.


What is this angle I am talking about?


When the spiral starts with every points all aligned from the center to an edge, this is the angle 0.0.
When the spiral rotate and form an horizontal line, we reached 0.5 (or PI or 180 degrees)
At that point, the spiral is rotating in opposite direction, unrolling until becoming a single line, which is the angle 0.99999 (or 2*PI or 359.9999 degrees)


Anyway, the video will give you an idea of how it feels to see this rotating spiral.

Fun fact: The weird patterns that appear from zooming out at 12:40 come are explained by the Nyquist–Shannon sampling theorem. It says that the sampling frequency (the pixels on your screen per distance) must be twice the frequency of the signal (the number of colour changes between yellow and black per distance) to properly reconstruct the original data (i.e. show the image properly). So if you have too few pixels for too many dots, it starts turning into weird patterns like that.

Okay, looking back over the puzzle, I want to emphasize something—the original bit of data visualization whimsy that led to these patterns, well, like, it doesn't matter. No one cares. There's nothing special about plotting (p, p) in polar coordinates. And most of the initial mystery in these spirals resulted from the artifacts that come from dealing with integer number of radians, which is kind of weird. But on the other hand, this kind of play is clearly worth it if the end result is a line of questions that leads you to something like Dirichlet's theorem, which is important; especially if it inspires you to learn enough to understand the tactics of the underlying proof. No small task, by the way.

And this isn't a coincidence, that a fairly random question like this can lead you to an important and deep fact for math. What it means for a piece of math to be "important" and "deep" is that it connects to many other topics. So even an arbitrary exploration of numbers, as long as it's not too arbitrary, has a good chance of stumbling into something meaningful. Sure, you'll get a much more concentrated dosage of important facts by going through a textbook or a course, and there will be many fewer uninteresting dead ends—but there is something special about rediscovering these topics on your own.

If you effectively reinvent Euler's totient function before you've ever seen it defined, or if you start wondering about rational approximations before learning about continued fractions, or if you seriously explore how primes are divvied up between residue classes before you've even heard the name Dirichlet; then when you do learn those topics, you'll see them as familiar friends, not as arbitrary definitions. And that will almost certainly mean that you learn it more effectively.

I'm probably making a bunch of assumptions (and extrapolating a finite case to an infinite case), but I find the evenness of primes to be pretty intuitive.

From the 1-3-7-9 point, the multiples of each prime will cycle through those four end digits before repeating any.

Removing all multiples of 3 will evenly distribute across the 4 sets, because of said cycle (in this case, 3,9,1,7,3,9,1,7,3...).

Multiples of 7 would do the same, except for common multiples of 3, since those would have already been removed in the previous step. However, comultiples will themselves be evenly distributed across the sets, since they are an unbroken set of multiples (of 7*3). This means that the skipped numbers are evenly distributed, and so all other multiples of 7 must be evenly distributed.

11 would also be evenly distributed, as its comultiples with 7, 3 and 7*3 would all be evenly distributed, and so a combination of adding and subtracting these sets of comultiples would also be evenly distributed.

i.e. m(11)-(m(11*3)+m(11*7)-m(11*7*3)) where m(n) is the number of multiples of n within each 1-3-7-9 set. Since m(n) will be the same value in each set, the result in each set will be the same.

This could be continued for each set of removed multiples, adding and subtracting sets of numbers which are each evenly distributed across the four sets.

If you intend on a follow-up, please do a video on sieve methods, Littlewood's theorem and especially Chebyshev's bias.
In short: The fact that in case n=8 in your last animation, the bar for r=1 continues to lag behind the other three bars is NOT a mere coincidence! For instance, this is even more prominent for n=120. 1 and 49 are both legal residue classes for primes, but doing the animation even up to a million and beyond, you see that these two residue classes continue to fall behind the others. Simply speaking, this stems directly from the fact that all squares of prime numbers fall into these special residue classes, so a number in one of these is slightly more likely to get killed in the sieve, despite Dirichlet's theorem.

The problem of figuring out patterns among primes is clear when considering the nature of the problem. While it's easy to begin with any whole number and form a series of multiples from it, prime numbers are whole numbers which are NOT multiples of smaller whole numbers. This makes the identification of primes an arduous process of finding entities which are the EXCEPTIONS to a rule in a thick field of entities which DO follow the rule.

What about Chebychev's bias? Yes, the ratio of primes in any of the residue classes all converge to the same value, but if you look at the TOTAL NUMBER of primes, rather than the ratio, then the residue classes that don't contain squares tend to have more primes.

Theory before watching: because prime numbers are the "holes" left by removing multiple from a number line. So, 2 is prime, then you remove every other multiple of 2. The next number is 3, so you remove all multiple of 3 from the number line. 4 was removed, 5 is next, remove every multiple of 5. etc. Which, when you start rotating around itself, means removing some kind of "line" from the picture.
